importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Andrew emailed Epstein on this date, stating they were 'in this together,' which contradicted earlier claims and fueled scrutiny over his relationship with Epstein and Giuffre.
Andrew gave up all public duties and charity roles in November 2019, marking a turning point in the royal family's distancing from his controversial behavior.
The latest probe by London police into Andrew's actions was announced on this date, indicating renewed public and institutional concern about royal accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2011 to 2025 encompasses the central controversy: Andrew's alleged request to use a bodyguard to investigate Giuffre's background, the 2019 demotion of duties, and the 2025 public probe, showing a sustained public and institutional reaction.

keyTakeAways: Prince Andrew allegedly asked a bodyguard officer to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record in 2011, raising serious ethical concerns about using royal security personnel in smear campaigns.

The revelation is tied to a broader scandal involving Andrew’s continued contact with Jeffrey Epstein, including an email from February 28, 2011, in which Andrew said they were 'in this together,' which contradicts claims he had severed ties with Epstein.

Giuffre, who was trafficked by Epstein in 2001, died by suicide in April 2025 at age 41; her family welcomed Andrew’s title relinquishment but called for King Charles III to strip his title as a form of accountability.
Andrew settled a civil suit with Giuffre in 2022, acknowledging her suffering as a victim of sex trafficking but refusing to admit wrongdoing or deny allegations.
British Energy Secretary Ed Miliband condemned the allegations, stating that it is inappropriate for a police bodyguard to be used in a smear campaign.

The probe by London Metropolitan Police is part of a wider effort to hold the royal family accountable for past misconduct and to protect the monarchy from reputational damage linked to Andrew’s actions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: British police are investigating whether Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, in 2011 asked a bodyguard officer to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record—allegedly to smear her as a sexual assault victim trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein. The probe follows revelations that Andrew maintained contact with Epstein as late as February 2011, contradicting prior claims, and comes amid public backlash over Andrew’s handling of the Epstein connection and denial of allegations. Giuffre, who died by suicide in April 2025, was a key accuser, and her family welcomed Andrew’s relinquishment of titles but urged the monarchy to take further action. Andrew settled a civil suit with Giuffre in 2022, admitting she suffered as a victim but denying wrongdoing. The case has sparked wider scrutiny of royal accountability, with officials like Ed Miliband condemning the use of security personnel in smear campaigns, and calls growing for King Charles III to revoke Andrew’s title as a symbolic act of justice.
title: Police Looking Into Whether Prince Andrew Enlisted Officer to Dig Up Dirt on Accuser Giuffre
